snippet: “Ghost Brothers of Darkland County,” the Southern gothic musical by Stephen King and John Mellencamp that opened at the Alliance Theater in Atlanta, has the feel of something devised over Skype.
abstract: Jason Zinoman reviews Stephen King and John Mellencamp play Ghost Brothers of Darkland County, directed by Susan V booth, at the Alliance Theater in Atlanta; Lucas Kavner and Justin Guarini star. Photo (M)
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA -- At the bloody heart of ''Ghost Brothers of Darkland County,'' the Southern gothic musical by Stephen King and John Mellencamp, is a tense sibling rivalry between a novelist with a dark streak and a blue-jeans-wearing crooner. Frank (Lucas Kavner) and Drake McCandless (Justin Guarini) are surely meant to evoke younger versions of the famous team that created them. The brothers are at odds over, among other things, the attention of their parents and the affections of a woman, but creating a musical can inspire just as much tension. Just ask Bono, another pop star moonlighting as a theater composer.

headline.main: These Ghosts Are Singing With a Southern Twang
